description.narrative: The project aims to strengthen capacities of the Advisory Group on the Rule of Law and Access to Justice, including state authorities and civil society representatives.

participating-org.narrative: OFFICE OF THE HIGH COMMISSIONER FOR HUMAN RIGHTS

provider-org.narrative: OFFICE OF THE HIGH COMMISSIONER FOR HUMAN RIGHTS
OFFICE OF THE HIGH COMMISSIONER FOR HUMAN RIGHTS

description.narrative: - Availability of the assessment on Rule of Law and Access to Justice to decision-makers and the public at large. - Number of round tables for working groups developing the rule of law and access to justice programme document with participation of the international experts. - Number of study visits for the representatives of state bodies developing the programme document on the Rule of Law and Access to Justice, including members of Advisory Group, to exchange experience and promote best practices in the area of rule of law and access to justice

comment.narrative: - No assessments available on Rule of Law and Access to Justice to decision-makers and the public at large. - No round tables held for working groups developing the rule of law and access to justice programme document with participation of the international experts - No study visits for the representatives of state bodies held aiming at developing the programme document on the Rule of Law and Access to Justice, including members of Advisory Group, to exchange experience and promote best practices in the area of rule of law and access to justice.

- To consider availability and feasibility of the assessment on Rule of Law and Access to Justice or on related issue to decision-makers and the public at large. - Number of round tables for working groups developing the rule of law and access to justice programme document with participation of the international experts. - Number of study visits for the representatives of state bodies developing the programme document on the Rule of Law and Access to Justice, including members of Advisory Group, to exchange experience and promote best practices in the area of rule of law and access to justice.

- Two round tables on access to justice for people with disabilities were conducted in two Belarusian region cities: Grodno and Brest. Main participants: local authorities involved in decision-making of laws and policies regulating people with disabilities. - Expert level consultations on the Reporting system to the United Nations human rights treaty bodies conducted in order to enhance cooperation between state authorities and CSO's representatives in drafting and submitting reports. - Study tour to the Netherlands on the topic “The experience of the best practitioners in the field of alternative dispute resolution on the example of the Netherlands” is conducted for 17 participants. - Republican seminar “Administrative procedures based on “one-stop-shop” principle: system improvement of work with citizens and business” is supported (70 participants). - Public consultations on drafting the first report on measures taken by the Republic of Belarus to implement the provisions of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities are supported (45 participants). - OGP Global Summit (Tbilisi, Georgia) - support for 6 participants from Belarus is provided. - Third International Conference on Access to Legal Aid in Criminal Justice Systems; facilitation of the breakout session on Barriers and Solutions to Providing Prompt Access to Legal Aid in Eurasia - support for 5 participants from Belarus is provided. - Round table "Place and role of human rights in the education system" is supported (37 participants).
Revision of draft law on the rights of persons with disabilities

During the round table 30 April 2019 the expert presented findings and recommendations for further work and improvement of the draft law on social integration of the people with disabilities. Participants of the round table received the access to the analytical document on the proposals for further amendments of the draft law; discussed and shared the main follow up strategies in disability rights field.
According to the findings, the draft law contains ambitious proposals that have a real potential to bring the national legislation to the high standard of human rights of persons with disabilities set by the Convention. Of particular significance are introduction of the definition of disability-based discrimination and prohibition of all its forms; the commitment to inclusive education of children with disabilities; articles regulating the provision of sign language interpretation; and the coordinated inter-agency framework.
Nevertheless, as the current version of the draft Law still contains a number of serious shortcomings that necessitates close attention and revision. Of concern are the narrow scope of the law, manifestly medical/charity–based approaches to disabilities, problems with the interpretation of the principle of reasonable accommodation and its difference from the principle of accessibility, as well as the absence of concrete and efficient sanctions and monitoring mechanisms (including independent monitoring).
